_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Organic Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Oxiteno USA, LLC (Oxiteno) owns and operates a chemical manufacturing facility located in Pasadena, Texas.  The facility is a batch chemical production plant that produces amphoteric surfactants, esters, and solutions for the agrochemical market.

  

The following information is intended to satisfy the requirements under 40 CFR ?68.155 regarding the Executive Summary of a United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Risk Management Plan (RMP).  In this facility, Oxiteno plans to handle Ethylene oxide (CAS 75-21-8) in volumes that exceed the threshold quantity (10,000 pounds) as prescribed under Table 1 of 40 CFR ?68.130.  Additionally, this proposed process is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standards under 29 CFR 1910.119 and is under Code 325199 of the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS).   As such, the Program 3 Prevention Program is applicable.



The RMP is maintained online via EPA's Central Data Exchange (CDX).  This document serves as a site copy of the RMP for Oxiteno to maintain at the Pasadena Plant for their records.  Any additions or updates to the RMP should be addressed within EPA's CDX and in this document to be maintained at the site.



1.1    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Ethylene oxide (EtO) is used as part of the ethoxylation process at the facility.  It is unloaded from railcars, stored in tanks, and used in site reactors.  The same properties that makes EtO valuable to Oxiteno's production process also makes it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling the substance to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own personal health and welfare as well as those of its employees, and to reduce the threat to the nearby population.  It is Oxiteno's policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which EtO is handled, the safety device

s inherent in the design of the facility, and the safe handling procedures that are used and the training provided to personnel.

Oxiteno's emergency response program is based upon Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Standards.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for the notification of the local emergency services and any affected neighbors in the vicinity of the site.  



1.2    STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

EtO is transported to the site in pressurized tanker rail cars and loaded into two 53,000 gallon pressurized bullet tanks for storage on site.  EtO is piped under its own pressure to various processes throughout the facility.  Access to the bullet tanks is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel, and authorized contractors.  The maximum amount of EtO that can be stored at the facility is 106,000 pounds.



1.3    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND                 CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with OSHA, the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA), and recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.  All employees have received on-the-job training and written testing regarding accidental release prevention.



1.4    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases from the covered process.  Specifically, there have been no accidental releases that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



1.5    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility's emergency response program is based upon OSHA Standards.  Oxiteno has discussed this program with local emergency response agencies, including the Pasadena Fire Department.



1.6    PLANN

ED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The facility was constructed in 2012 and is in compliance with OSHA Standards 1910 and 1926.  The EtO Process installation will occur in 2017, and will be in compliance with these standards.
